title: Adapting Conventional SEM and STEM Instruments for Acquisition of Electron-Beam Induced Current (EBIC) Images
content: Electron-beam induced current (EBIC) imaging is a powerful technique that enables to achieve structure-property relationships by mapping the electrical response of a sample as a function of the incident electron probe position. Typically, when used in an SEM, EBIC is very useful to map the quality of solar cell devices (e.g. measuring the density of defects) as the beam scans the local beam-induced electron-hole creation cross-section across the sample [1]. In the scanning transmission electron microscope (STEM), secondary electron (SE) EBIC (SEEBIC) imaging is applied to study diverse electronic materials, such as mapping the electron density in 2D materials or visualizing the formation of conducting paths in resistive switching devices [2, 3].
